details.title: Analysis of generalized phased-mission system reliability, performance, and sensitivity

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Electr. & Comput. Eng., Virginia Univ., Charlottesville, VA, USA

p: Liudong Xing received the B.S. degree (1996) in computer science from ZhengZhou University, P.R. China, and served as a graduate research assistant in ShenYang Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Science, China from 1996 to 1998. She received the M.S. degree (2000) in electrical engineering from the University of Virginia, Charlottesville.

She is now working toward the Ph.D. degree in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Virginia. Her major interests are in the design and analysis of reliable systems. Her current interests focus on reliability analysis of phased-mission systems and networks. She is a Student Member of the IEEE.

authors.name: Liudong Xing

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Electr. & Comput. Eng., Virginia Univ., Charlottesville, VA, USA

p: Joanne Bechta Dugan (F'00) received the B.A. degree (1980) in mathematics and computer science from La Salle University, Philadelphia, PA, and the M.S. (1982) and Ph.D. (1984) degrees in electrical engineering from Duke University, Durham, NC.

She is Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Virginia. She has performed and directed research on the development and application of techniques for the analysis of computer systems which are designed to tolerate hardware and software faults. Her research interests thus include hardware and software reliability engineering, fault-tolerant computing, and mathematical modeling using dynamic fault trees, Markov models, Petri nets, and simulation.

Dr. Dugan is an IEEE Fellow, was Associate Editor of the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON RELIABILITY for 10 years, and is Associate Editor of the IEEE TRANSACTIONS SOFTWARE ENGINEERING. She served on the National Research Council Committee on Application of Digital Instrumentation and Control Systems to Nuclear Power Plant Operations and Safety.

authors.name: J.B. Dugan

details.abstract: This paper proposes a generalized phased-mission system (GPMS) analysis methodology called GPMS-CPR that has high computation efficiency and is easy to implement. GPMS-CPR can evaluate a wider range of more practical systems with less restrictive mission requirements, while offering more human-friendly performance indices such as multilevel grading as compared to the previous PMS approaches. GPMS-CPR also accounts for imperfect coverage. This method implements an exciting synthesis of several approaches into a single methodology. Further, it extends the methodology to allow for the analysis of sensitivity of each component for each phase as well as for the entire phased mission, with respect to the multilevel reliability for the GPMS. The conventional phase-OR PMS appear as a special case this GPMS. The advantages of this approach are in the low computational complexity, broad applicability, easy implementation, and high integration (reliability, performance, and sensitivity for GPMS). The methodology is illustrated with examples.

references.title: Quantitative reliability evaluation of repairable phased-mission systems using Markov approach

context.text: Thus, the reliability of a conventional phase-OR PMS is the probability that the mission successfully achieves the objectives in all phases [1].
Markov-chain based methods [1], [6], [13], etc., account for the \$s\$-dependence across the phases by constructing one or more Markov chains.

links.abstract: A quantitative reliability model for a phased mission system is developed using a Markov process. Two cases for the mission-phase change times are assumed: 1) to be known in advance and 2) to be random variables. A method of solution is presented and illustrated by examples. The solution of phased-mission systems is equivalent to solving a sequence of uni-phase systems with appropriate initial conditions.

references.text: M. Alam, U. M. Al-Saggaf, "Quantitative reliability evaluation of repairable phased-mission systems using Markov approach", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-35, pp. 498-503, Dec. 1986.

references.title: A separable method for incorporating imperfect coverage in combinatorial model

context.text: References [2]and [15] present a new separable approach, SEA, for incorporating IPC into a combinatorial model for single-phased mission systems.
References [2] and [15] present a new separable approach, SEA, for incorporating IPC into a combinatorial model.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new method for incorporating imperfect FC (fault coverage) into a combinatorial model. Imperfect FC, the probability that a single malicious fault can thwart automatic recovery mechanisms, is important to accurate reliability assessment of fault-tolerant computer systems. Until recently, it was thought that the consideration of this probability necessitated a Markov model rather than the simpler (and usually faster) combinatorial model. SEA, the new approach, separates the ...

references.title: Reliability and Risk Assessment

context.text: Sensitivity analysis, also called importance analysis [3], [10], helps identify which components contribute most to system unreliability or performance and thus would be good candidates for upgrade.
The sensitivity to an input parameter is most often defined as the partial derivative of the reliability with respect to that parameter (Birnbaum's measure [3], [10]).

links.abstract: A new algorithm combines a coverage model with a combinatorial model to compute system unreliability. Its advantage is that for a class of computer systems, it is simpler than current algorithms. The method applies to combinatorial models which can generate cutsets for the system. This set of cutsets is augmented with cutsets representing the uncovered failures of the system. The resulting set is manipulated by combining standard multi-state and sum-of-disjoint products solution techniques. It i...

references.text: S. A. Doyle, J. B. Dugan, A. Patterson-Hine, "A combinatorial approach to modeling imperfect coverage", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 44, pp. 87-94, Mar. 1995.

links.abstract: A method for automated analysis of phased mission reliability which considers the problem in terms of the construction of a continuous-time discrete-state Markov model and uses a standard Markov-chain solution technique that is adapted to the problem of phased missions is presented. The resulting state space is the union of the states in each independent phase, rather than the sum. This results in a model that can be substantially smaller than those required by other methods. A unified framework...

references.text: J. B. Dugan, "Automated analysis of phased-mission reliability", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 40, Apr. 1991.

links.abstract: Several different models for predicting coverage in a fault-tolerant system, including models for permanent, intermittent, and transient errors, are discussed. Markov, semi-Markov, nonhomogeneous Markov, and extended stochastic Petri net models for computing coverage are developed. Two types of events that interfere with recovery are examined; and methods for modeling such events, whether they are deterministic or random, are given. The sensitivity of system reliability/availability to the cover...

links.abstract: Systems requiring very high levels of reliability, such as aircraft controls or spacecraft, often use redundancy to achieve their requirements. This paper provides highly efficient techniques for computing the reliability of redundant systems involving simple k-out-of-n arrangements, and those involving complex structures which may include imbedded k-out-of-n structures. Techniques for modeling systems subject to imperfect fault coverage must be appropriate to the red...

links.abstract: Three assumptions of Markov modeling for reliability of phased-mission systems that limit flexibility of representation are identified. The proposed generalization has the ability to represent state-dependent behavior, handle phases of random duration using globally time-dependent distributions of phase change time, and model globally time-dependent failure and repair rates. The approach is based on a single nonhomogeneous Markov model in which the concept of state transition is extended to incl...

references.title: A BDD-based algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems

context.text: a BDD-based PMS approach [16].
The PMS-BDD method [16] gives a good unreliability evaluation algorithm for static PMS based on BDD.
Reference [16]proves these rules by using the relation between the component and the mini-component: \$A_j=a_1\cdot a_2 \cdot\,\cdots\,\cdot a_j\$.
Reference [16]presents a 5-step PMS-BDD algorithm which uses phase algebra to combine the BDD for each phase to obtain the final BDD.
Reference [16] derives the formulas for evaluating each node in the final BDD.
The PMS-BDD approach [16] gave a good unreliability-evaluation algorithm for conventional phase-OR PMS.
Order components using heuristics and backward PDO [16]; then generate BDD for each phase.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new algorithm (PMS-BDD) based on the binary decision diagram (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS). PMS-BDD uses phase algebra to deal with the dependence across the phases, and a new BDD operation to incorporate the phase algebra. Due to the nature of the BDD, cancellation of common components among the phases can be combined with the BDD generation, without additional operations; and the sum of disjoint products (SDP) can be implicitly represented...
